Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Mesoporous poorly crystalline α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> with abundant oxygen vacancies and acid sites for ozone decomposition.

AbstractText: In this work, mesoporous poorly crystalline hematite (α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) was prepared using mesoporous silica (KIT-6) functionalized with 3-[(2-aminoethyl)amino]propyltrimethoxysilane as a hard template (SMPC-α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>). The disordered atomic arrangement structure of SMPC-α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies, which was confirmed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), O<sub>2</sub>-temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), H<sub>2</sub>-temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) analyses. Density functional theory calculations (DFT) also proved that reducing the crystallinity of α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> decreased the formation energy of oxygen vacancies. TPD and in situ DRIFT analyses of NH<sub>3</sub> adsorption suggested that the surface acidity of SMPC-α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> was considerably higher than those of mesoporous poorly crystalline α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (MPC-α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) and highly crystalline α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (HC-α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>). The oxygen vacancies and acid sites formed on α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> surface are beneficial for ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) decomposition. Compared with MPC-α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and HC-α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, SMPC-α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> exhibited a higher removal efficiency for 200-ppm O<sub>3</sub> at a space velocity of 720 L g<sup>-1</sup> h<sup>-1</sup> at 25 ± 2 °C under dry conditions. Additionally, in situ DRIFT and XPS results suggested that the accumulation of peroxide (O<sub>2</sub><sup>2-</sup>) and the conversion of O<sub>2</sub><sup>2-</sup> to lattice oxygen over the oxygen vacancies caused catalyst deactivation. However, O<sub>2</sub><sup>2-</sup> could be desorbed completely by continuous N<sub>2</sub> purging at approximately 350 °C. This study provides significant insights for developing highly active α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> catalysts for O<sub>3</sub> decomposition.
